metadata.case_name: S. K. Dutt & Ors. v. State

facts.text: S. K. Dutt carried on business as a building contractor under the name British India Construction Company with a branch at Asansol in charge of J. K. Bose.
In May 1942, military took up construction of dumps and roads in Asansol area; R. W. Mathams was Garrison Engineer, P. C. Ghose overseer under him.
On or about 10th May 1942, order placed with S. K. Dutt for construction of dumps at Burnpur near Asansol; works executed in June-July 1942; Rs. 1,74,000 paid on account.

Prosecution case: Amount paid was excess by Rs. 56,000 over works done; appellants conspired to avoid refund by S. K. Dutt claiming payment for roads purportedly ordered by R. W. Mathams on 7th July 1942 (Exhibit 10), measured by P. C. Ghose, bill passed for Rs. 1,89,458-14-0 on 15th March 1943 (Exhibit 6).
Roads alleged to have been constructed by S. K. Dutt were actually constructed by military; order dated 7th July 1942 created in March 1943.
Bribe of Rs. 30,000 agreed for passing bill; S. K. Dutt sent cheque to J. K. Bose on 16th March 1943; Rs. 18,000 paid to R. W. Mathams and Rs. 12,000 to P. C. Ghose on 17th March 1943.
Appellants denied conspiracy; stated roads constructed by S. K. Dutt; Rs. 30,000 for sub-contractors who constructed roads; produced receipts (Exhibit 27 series).
Special Tribunal acquitted on conspiracy but convicted on bribery on 9th May 1946.
High Court (Clough and Ellis JJ.) on 14th July 1947 dismissed appellants' appeals against bribery conviction, allowed Government appeal against acquittal on conspiracy; convicted on both.
Complaint instituted 7th June 1945; prosecution witnesses examined from 6th Sept 1945 to 29th March 1946.
J. K. Bose filed list of 15 witnesses on 27th March 1946 (mostly re Exhibit 27).
On 29th March 1946, order passed in absence of appellants: summons for 8th April 1946 by ordinary post (not per ss.68-69 CrPC); some returned undelivered.
On 8th April 1946, Tribunal refused further process; decided case and convicted on bribery.
Federal Court on 23rd April 1948 set aside convictions for contravention of s.257 CrPC; remanded for re-hearing after opportunity to examine witnesses.
High Court on 2nd August 1948 adjourned appeals till disposal of R.W. Mathams' Privy Council appeal.
Privy Council special leave to R.W. Mathams on 13th Nov 1947 limited to s.197 CrPC; enlarged on 5th Aug 1948 to include s.257 CrPC; transferred to Supreme Court.
High Court on 9th April 1951 ordered remanded appeals for hearing 11th June 1951; steps for witnesses.
List filed 8th May 1951: addresses of only 6/15 witnesses; B.C. Mukherjee and R.K. Paul examined; others unavailable (dead, migrated to East Pakistan, left place).
High Court on 6th Sept 1951 convicted S.K. Dutt, J.K. Bose, P.C. Ghose on both charges.
Burnpur was petty township prominent due to WWII military works; sub-contractors flocked and left post-1945.
Partition of Bengal 1947 led to migration.

legal_issues.text: Whether trial vitiated by contravention of section 257 CrPC due to refusal of process for defence witnesses and denial of reasonable opportunity to examine them on remand.
Whether sanction under section 197 CrPC required for prosecution on charges of conspiracy and bribery.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial vitiated as no reasonable opportunity to examine witnesses listed on 27th March 1946 due to Tribunal's refusal of process on 8th April 1946 contravening s.257 CrPC and delays on remand.
Roads constructed by S.K. Dutt via sub-contractors; Rs.30,000 paid to them per Exhibit 27; witnesses material to prove this.
Proceedings bad for want of sanction u/s 197 CrPC (R.W. Mathams only).

respondent_arguments.text: Excess payment of Rs.56,000; fake road construction claim, backdated order, bribe paid.

court_reasoning.text: Federal Court held s.257 CrPC contravened by Tribunal's 8th April 1946 order; witnesses material for both charges; remand required opportunity which was denied due to High Court delay till 1951; by then most witnesses untraceable due to post-war migration and partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants not to blame for situation; unsafe to convict without their evidence; no fair trial.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution evidence strong but appellants entitled to rebut via Exhibit 27 witnesses; two witnesses examined supported sub-contractors' existence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules of procedure must be scrupulously followed.

court_reasoning.text: No sanction u/s 197 needed per precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Covered by H.H.B. Gill and Phanindra Chandra Neogy.

holdings.text: Convictions set aside for contravention of s.257 CrPC and denial of fair trial; no need for s.197 sanction.
Sanction u/s 197 not required for conspiracy and bribery charges against public servant.

precedents_cited.relevance: No sanction u/s 197 CrPC needed for conspiracy/bribery prosecution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: No sanction u/s 197 CrPC needed for conspiracy/bribery prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction not required u/s 197; s.257 imperative, process cannot be refused without reasons; violated leading to no fair trial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; convictions of all appellants (S.K. Dutt, J.K. Bose, P.C. Ghose, R.W. Mathams) on conspiracy and bribery set aside; acquitted due to no fair trial from s.257 CrPC violation and denied opportunity to examine witnesses.

key_quotes.text: It is essential that rules of procedure designed to ensure justice, should be scrupulously followed, and Courts should be jealous in seeing that there is no breach of them.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Whatever one may think of the merits of the appellants' contention, they cannot be convicted without an opportunity being given to them to present their evidence, and that having been denied to them, there has been no fair trial.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for acquittal despite strong prosecution case.
